author: zkfloof
content: is it possible to hand over the private keys of an account onto the control of another account?

author: zkfloof
content: for example when users move their funds onto a new address but want to keep control of all of their previous addresses

author: zkfloof
content: would be nice not to have to store private keys for all your historical accounts but just pass on control to your latest active account

author: zkfloof
content: would eip3071 make something like this possible for non smart contract accounts?

author: halfinney.
content: can someone tell me if Filecoin has the same existing spec for 1559 in prod?

author: ajsutton
content: Same mechanics but not the same spec because the 1559 spec is necessarily about how to fit those mechanics into Ethereum

author: sky.cactus
content: It is for 3074.  This is actually a great use case that you should mention in <#718596092828057631>!

author: sky.cactus
content: Well, it *sort of* is possible.  Before you burn your private key you can sign over full control to a contract, and then that contract's owner could be your new keys.  When you burn your new keys (to rotate them again), you would change ownership of the contract to your new keys and then do a 3074 transaction to give total power to the root contract again.

author: mightypenguin
content:
Aren't these validator payment methods equal though?
A) Validator active all the time making 0.8 ETH per year.
B)  Validator sleeping 20% of the time with a reward of 1.0ETH per year. (Effectively 0.8ETH/year)

Scenario A) is much easier to reason about (I know I will always make .00xxxxx ETH per day per validator).
While B) has more payment jank. So it's less "home" user friendly.
Or am I missing something?

author: .vbuterin
content: The difference is that in case A, if you perform poorly, 20% of the time you still get the maximum reward
